title: 111_hr2424
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009". It includes findings related to the Federal Reserve. The Congress found that in August 2007, liquidity dried up in credit and securities markets, initially affecting financial firms with interests in mortgage-backed securities. This lack of credit access spread globally, leading to the Federal Reserve establishing a target range of 0 to 0.25 percent for the Federal funds rate in December 2008. The Federal Reserve established a target range of 0 to 0.25 percent for the Federal funds rate in December 2008 in response to the financial crisis, exercising its authority to address "unusual and exigent circumstances" multiple times since then. During the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve addressed unusual and exigent circumstances by extending assistance to nonmember institutions and purchasing debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises. Additionally, joint programs with the Department of the Treasury were established to aid financial markets. During the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve established joint programs with the Department of the Treasury to aid financial markets, guaranteeing assets of Citigroup and Bank of America. Chairman Ben Bernanke affirmed commitment to transparency in lending programs and balance sheet. SEC. 3. REVIEWS OF SPECIAL FEDERAL RESERVE CREDIT FACILITIES. Section 714 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General to conduct reviews of credit facilities established by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or any Federal reserve bank. This includes onsite examinations when deemed necessary. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 allows the Board or any Federal reserve bank to establish credit facilities for temporary assistance to private institutions as the lender of last resort. The credit facilities covered by this act include the Money Market Investor Funding Facility and the Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility. The facilities covered by the Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 include the Money Market Investor Funding Facility, Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility, Term Auction Facility, Primary Dealer Credit Facility, Commercial Paper Funding Facility, Term Securities Lending Facility, Maiden Lane LLCs, Revolving Credit Facility, and reciprocal currency arrangements with foreign central banks. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 covers various facilities including Maiden Lane LLCs, Revolving Credit Facility, reciprocal currency arrangements with foreign central banks, Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program, and special purpose vehicles conducting lending activities. The authority granted by the Act will expire after a 5-year period from enactment, and a report on each review conducted must be submitted. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 covers various facilities and will expire after a 5-year period from enactment. A report on each review conducted must be submitted to Congress within 90 days of completion, including findings, conclusions, and recommendations by the Comptroller General. SEC. 4. ACCESS TO RECORDS. Access to Records under Section 714(d)(1) and (2) of title 31, United States Code is amended to grant the Comptroller General access to agency records and credit facility records. The Comptroller General can request access to officers, employees, contractors, and representatives at any reasonable time and make copies of records as deemed appropriate. Unauthorized access is prohibited, with the inclusion of copies of records in the amendment. The Comptroller General is granted access to agency records and credit facility records under Section 714(d)(1) and (2) of title 31, United States Code. Unauthorized access is prohibited, and copies of records can be made as deemed appropriate.
